notes.title: Nature, Scope & Importance of Criminology (with Pakistan focus)
notes.content: Criminology studies crime, criminals, victims, and social reactions to crime using scientific methods. Scope spans criminal law, causes of crime, measurement, prevention, and policy. In Pakistan, scope extends to reforms in policing (Police Order 2002), juvenile justice (JJSA 2018), cybercrime (PECA 2016), forensic capacity (PFSA), and counter-terrorism/CVE policies.
keyTakeaways: Criminology integrates theory, empirical methods, and policy evaluation.
Pakistan's reforms shape applied criminology: policing, juvenile justice, cybercrime, forensics.
Evidence-based approaches and human-rights safeguards are essential.

notes.title: Defining Crime, Deviance, Sin & Vice; Typologies of Criminal Behavior
notes.content: Crime: legal violation; deviance: norm violation; sin: religious transgression; vice: moral failing (often legally permitted). Typologies classify behavior by legal category, motive, method, or offender characteristics (e.g., violent vs. property; white-collar; organized; cyber; juvenile).
keyTakeaways: Distinguish legal vs. moral vs. social norms.
Typologies aid risk assessment, prevention, and sentencing.
Overlap exists; categories are tools, not essences.

notes.title: Classical & Biological Perspectives
notes.content: Classical school (free will, deterrence) underpins proportionality. Early biological ideas (phrenology/physiognomy) are discredited historically but important context. Contemporary biosocial research considers genetics, neurobiology, and environment with ethical safeguards.
keyTakeaways: Deterrence informs sentencing and policing visibility.
Historical biological theories explain the evolution of thought, not current policy.
Modern biosocial work must avoid determinism and respect rights.

notes.title: Sociological Theories I: Anomie & Strain
notes.content: Merton's Anomie/Strain: crime arises when cultural goals (e.g., success) are emphasized but legitimate means are blocked, producing adaptations (innovation, ritualism, retreatism, rebellion).
keyTakeaways: Links structural inequality to crime rates.
Policy: expand legitimate opportunities; reduce strain via education, jobs.

notes.title: Sociological Theories II: Differential Association
notes.content: Sutherland: criminal behavior is learned through interaction in intimate groups; crime occurs when definitions favorable to violation outweigh unfavorable ones.
keyTakeaways: Focus on learning processes and peer networks.
Implications for prevention via pro-social associations.

notes.title: Sociological Theories III: Social Bond/Control
notes.content: Hirschi: crime occurs when bonds to society (attachment, commitment, involvement, belief) are weak or broken.
keyTakeaways: Prevention strengthens pro-social bonds (family, school, work).
Explains age–crime curve and informal controls.

notes.title: Sociological Theories IV: Labeling
notes.content: Labelling theory: social reaction and stigmatizing labels can amplify deviance (secondary deviance). Youth are particularly vulnerable; diversion and restorative approaches mitigate harms.
keyTakeaways: Focus on consequences of official reactions.
Promotes diversion, sealing records, rehabilitation.

notes.title: Realist Perspectives & Key Concepts
notes.content: Left realism emphasizes relative deprivation and community responses; right realism stresses control, deterrence, and routine activity guardianship. Historical biological notions (phrenology/physiognomy) are referenced only as contrasts.
keyTakeaways: Realist views inform practical policy mixes: prevention + enforcement.
Balance social programs with situational crime prevention.

notes.title: Juvenile Delinquency: Definitions, Causes, Risk/Protective Factors
notes.content: Juvenile delinquency involves offenses committed by minors. Risk factors: poverty, school failure, peer deviance, trauma; protective factors: family support, mentoring, pro-social activities, education.
keyTakeaways: Multi-level risks; interventions must be family-, school-, and community-based.
Diversion and probation reduce labeling harms.

notes.title: Pakistan's Juvenile Justice: Law & Practice
notes.content: JJSA 2018 introduced diversion, age determination, legal aid, and specialized courts; implementation challenges persist (capacity, resources). Probation services derive from the Probation of Offenders Ordinance 1960 and related rules.
keyTakeaways: JJSA centers diversion and rehabilitation.
Coordination across police, prosecution, courts, social services is crucial.

notes.title: Principles of Criminal Investigation
notes.content: Core principles: preserve life; secure and preserve the scene; document thoroughly; maintain continuity/chain of custody; follow legal/rights-compliant procedures; integrate forensics; maintain objectivity.
keyTakeaways: First responder actions determine evidential integrity.
Documentation + chain of custody underpin admissibility.

notes.title: Crime Scene Search Patterns & Documentation
notes.content: Common patterns: spiral, strip/line, grid, zone/quadrant, wheel/ray—selected by scene layout and resources. Documentation: notes, photographs, sketches, evidence logs; establish entry/exit log and cordons.
keyTakeaways: Choose patterns to maximize coverage and minimize contamination.
Documentation must be contemporaneous and complete.

notes.title: Interviewing vs. Interrogation & Human Rights
notes.content: Modern practice favors rapport-based investigative interviewing over accusatory interrogation. The Méndez Principles set science-, law-, and ethics-based standards: plan, build rapport, open questions, record, ensure legal safeguards (lawyer, doctor, notification), reject coercion/torture.
keyTakeaways: Effective interviews elicit reliable information and reduce false confessions.
Audio-video recording and early access to counsel are key safeguards.

notes.title: Forensic Science in Pakistan (PFSA & Practice)
notes.content: PFSA provides multidisciplinary services (DNA, crime scene, fingerprints, firearms, digital forensics). Proper evidence packaging, sealing, and paperwork are mandatory for admissibility.
keyTakeaways: Coordinate early with PFSA to select appropriate tests.
Scene processing quality directly affects lab outcomes.

notes.title: Policing in Pakistan: History, Structure & Reforms
notes.content: Colonial legacy (Police Act 1861) → reforms via Police Order 2002 emphasizing accountability bodies, public safety commissions, and service orientation. Further provincial adaptations and ongoing reform debates.
keyTakeaways: Shift from force-centric to service-oriented policing remains a work in progress.
Legal architecture matters for legitimacy and effectiveness.

notes.title: International Police Cooperation: INTERPOL, EUROPOL & IPA
notes.content: INTERPOL connects NCBs (I-24/7), notices (incl. new Silver Notice for asset tracing), and analytical support; EUROPOL supports EU Member States with ECTC and analysis projects; the International Police Association (IPA) is a professional friendship/learning network enhancing cooperation.
keyTakeaways: INTERPOL facilitates data/intelligence sharing and asset recovery.
EUROPOL provides operational analysis hubs (e.g., ECTC).
IPA fosters professional exchange and trust across borders.

notes.title: Cybercrime: Law, Prevention & Digital Evidence
notes.content: PECA 2016 criminalizes unauthorized access, cyber terrorism, hate speech online, etc. Digital evidence handling requires rapid preservation, imaging, and chain of custody; first-responder actions are critical.
keyTakeaways: Use standard digital evidence protocols; avoid altering data.
Early engagement with specialized cyber units (FIA CCW) is essential.

notes.title: Money Laundering: FATF Standards, TBML & Crypto Risks
notes.content: Pakistan's AML framework is anchored in AMLA 2010 and amendments, aligned to FATF 40 Recommendations. High-risk typologies include trade-based money laundering (TBML), misuse of MVTS/hawala, and virtual assets.
keyTakeaways: Risk-based AML/CFT controls must cover TBML and virtual assets.
International cooperation (INTERPOL IFCACC; FIUs) is vital.

notes.title: Juvenile Probation: Organization & Administration
notes.content: Probation provides community-based supervision with conditions and rehabilitative services. In Pakistan, statutory basis is the Probation of Offenders Ordinance 1960 and provincial rules; coordination with social welfare departments is typical.
keyTakeaways: Individualized case plans, graduated responses, family involvement.
Clear reporting, curfew/attendance conditions, education/vocational support.

notes.title: Recidivism: Institutional & Community Corrections
notes.content: Recidivism is reduced through evidence-based corrections: cognitive-behavioral programs, education, vocational training, substance use treatment, family reintegration, and post-release supervision. Community corrections (probation, parole, community service) often outperform incarceration for low-risk offenders.
keyTakeaways: Match interventions to risk/need (RNR model).
Aftercare and reintegration planning start at intake.

notes.title: Criminal Courts in Pakistan: Procedures & Challenges
notes.content: Criminal process under CrPC: investigation, charge, trial, evidence, appeal. Procedural delays, resources, and witness protection are key challenges; reforms aim at speed, fairness, and due process.
keyTakeaways: Understand CrPC structure to map bottlenecks.
Fair-trial rights (e.g., Article 10A) must be operationalized.

notes.title: Community Policing: Philosophy, Strategies & Evaluation
notes.content: Community policing rests on partnerships + problem solving (SARA). Strategies include joint problem analysis, transparency, foot patrols, youth engagement, and accountability. Benefits: trust, tailored prevention, legitimacy; challenges: sustaining resources, measuring outcomes.
keyTakeaways: Treat community as co-producer of safety.
Use evidence (hot spots, problem-oriented policing) alongside COP.

notes.title: Radicalization: Definitions, Factors & Prevention
notes.content: Radicalization is a process leading some individuals toward violent extremism; influenced by push/pull factors (grievances, identity needs, networks, propaganda). Prevention emphasizes whole-of-society approaches, human rights, youth empowerment, education, and community resilience.
keyTakeaways: Address both structural drivers and individual pathways.
Programs should be context-specific and rights-compliant.

notes.title: Intelligence-Led Policing (ILP) & Organized Crime
notes.content: ILP uses crime analysis and criminal intelligence to prioritize prolific offenders and serious harm. Coordination with financial crime units and international partners (INTERPOL, EUROPOL) is key against organized crime, trafficking, and money laundering.
keyTakeaways: Data-driven targeting of serious harm improves resource allocation.
Link ILP with AML/CFT and asset recovery.
